history.content:
It's very important for ML/AI, the entire ML was based on probability and CS70 is not enough. It would be a good preparation for CS189 as well. I am not sure about its application in robotics but eecs126 is indeed some foundation thing for all ee fields.

In 126 there are labs that apply the probability theory on topics such as auction, simulating distribution, hmm, expectation maximization, viterbi algorithm, huffman encoding, RNA sequencing, etc. Really recommend!

It's very important for ML/AI, the entire ML was based on probability and CS70 is not enough. It would be a good preparation for CS189 as well. I am not sure about its application in robotics but eecs126 is indeed some foundation thing for all ee fields.

children.subject: Ah, thanks for making my perception of 126 positive once again! Out of curiosity, for signal processing, what were some of the other "most useful" classes you've taken here?
120 has been by far the most useful because of how fundamental it is. 61C, 123, and 126 have all been very useful as well. I’m taking it next semester, but I’m told 127’s also a good class for it.

I do signal processing stuff, and I'd easily put 126 in the top 3 most useful classes I've taken here. In your question, you say: "So I wonder, for a class that is literally just a whole bunch of probability theory...". This isn't true - only the first third of the class is pure probability theory. The rest is a sampling of other topics such as random processes, hypothesis testing, inference, and other things like the student answer mentions. The labs are really cool!

I think people do 126 a disservice in only advertising it as a 189 feeder class - I'd argue it's absolutely essential if you want to go into any of the more math-y/theoretical EE disciplines as well, and as a nice side effect it will also help develop those intangibles like "mathematical maturity" that are valuable.

126 is important for robotics - one of the books that revolutionized the field and more or less made self-driving cars possible was Probabilistic Robotics (Thrun, Burgard, Fox). Considering uncertainty in robot measurements and actions was crucial to making progress on some very challenging perception problems.

history.content:
I just finished CS70 and I must say that class was a hell of a timesink. Seeing the curriculum of EE126, it really does look like CS70 on steroids. I also keep being told left and right that it is useful for ML among many other fields. 

At the moment, I'm interested in delving into either Natural Language Processing or maybe Robotics (so like signals and control classes I assume). So I wonder, for a class that is literally just a whole bunch of probability theory, how useful is EE126 for these two fields (or in general), and how are concepts in this class applied to such fields?
history.subject: How Useful is EE126?
